info: In French, states and conditions are often expressed differently than in English. For personal states like hunger, thirst, or fear, French uses "avoir" (to have), e.g., J'ai faim ("I am hungry," literally "I have hunger"). Weather conditions typically use "il fait" (it makes), e.g., Il fait chaud ("It is hot," literally "It makes heat"). Temporary states or emotions often use "être" (to be), e.g., Je suis fatigué ("I am tired").  French externalizes some experiences and treats others as possessions, creating a distinct perspective compared to English.

Temporary states or emotions often use "être" (to be), e.g., Je suis fatigué ("I am tired").  French externalizes some experiences and treats others as possessions, creating a distinct perspective compared to English.
